text:
The default value for the "Group" directive in httpd.conf is
"#-1". Up to now this maps to GID=65535, which is most often
the GID for group "nogroup" or similar.

Since linux kernel v2.6 UIDs and GIDs can be 32 bit (I have
this configuration), so that -1 now maps to
(2^32)-1. All users that belong to a group "nogroup" (GID=65535)
do *not* neccessarily also belong to a group with the
GID (2^32)-1.

This should be fixed by specifing "Group nogroup" as default value,
because many people do not change this setting (because they
don't understand it *g*).

(This misbehaviour caused strange bugs when executing CGIs
that *should* have permissions to do certain things (because
group "nogroup" was allowed to do these actions), but the
scripts always failed with "permission denied" (because they
did not run as "nogroup", but as group with GID=2^32-1))
creator: kleiner77@gmx.net

text:
User/Group and ServerName are three things that pretty much everyone can expect
to need to change in httpd.conf.  There is no default value that we can give
that would satisfy the majority of users.  Although "nogroup" may work well for
specific versions of linux, it won't work for many other platforms.  And the
failure case of not having enough permissions is better than the altenative
failure cases (too much permissions or apache failing to start).
creator: slive@apache.org
